image.altText: A woman outside a court building in handcuffs.

props.synopsis: A court has heard harrowing accounts from emergency services and the siblings of a young girl who died after her mother criminally neglected her. Warning: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this article contains the first name and image of a person who has died. Readers are also advised this story contains content which may be distressing.

title.children: Mother had 'callous disregard' for dying daughter, court told

image.altText: A teenaged boy in a green school uniform sitting at a table with other students speaking to a man in a fluro vest.

props.synopsis: When former police detective turned educator Luke Taylor swapped his badge and gun for a classroom, he realised his crime-solving skills could apply to multiple career pathways.

title.children: Crime-solving workshop teaches transferable skills for future careers

image.altText: A close-up of an emotional jockey with her hand over her mouth as she rides back after winning the Melbourne Cup.

props.synopsis: Half Yours wins the 165th edition of the Melbourne Cup at Flemington, with jockey Jamie Melham making history as the first female jockey to win both the Melbourne and Caulfield Cups.

title.children: 'He's up there': Melham's tribute to late grandfather after Cup win

image.altText: Two teen boys smiling as they look at their laptops in a library with shelves full of books

props.synopsis: After escaping the Syrian civil war as a young boy, Mazen Al Jahed is one of thousands of South Australian students preparing for their year 12 exams.

title.children: Young Syrian refugees overcome life challenges to take on year 12 exams

image.altText: A man in a khaki shirt holds up a mouse.

props.synopsis: The CSIRO is urging farmers to reduce opportunities for mice breeding this harvest season as the threat of a pest population boom looms.

title.children: Worrying signs another mouse plague could be on the way

image.altText: A large blue sculpture with googly eyes on it at night

props.synopsis: A 19-year-old woman appears in court via telephone accused of damaging Mount Gambier's Cast in Blue sculpture, which has drawn criticism for its cost and appearance.

title.children: Woman in court for putting googly eyes on controversial 'Blue Blob' sculpture

image.altText: Oyster production at Coffin Bay on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula.

props.synopsis: A blockade at a boat ramp to prevent oysters from entering an open fishing bay, over fears of spreading the algal bloom, leads to the destruction of nearly $70,000 worth of oysters.

title.children: Blockade halts oyster relocation as nearly $70k worth destroyed

image.altText: A woman and a man walk through glass doors, leaving a building

props.synopsis: A girl who died, allegedly as a result of criminal neglect by her mother, had resorted to eating food out of bins at her school, a court has heard. Warning: This story includes references to child abuse and self-harm.

title.children: Alleged manslaughter victim resorted to eating from school bins, court told

image.altText: David Speirs giving a press conference in front of a beach in Adelaide.

props.synopsis: Former South Australian opposition leader David Speirs says he will make a decision about his political future in the coming weeks as he launches his own plans for the algal bloom.

title.children: Former SA opposition leader David Speirs to make decision on political future by the end of year

image.altText: The South Australia Police logo on a building.

props.synopsis: Three arrests have been made in two separate incidents in regional South Australia, one in which a man allegedly lit a fire before throwing a rock at firefighters and another involving a car being discovered in flames after allegedly leaving a "trail of destruction" on a property.

title.children: Charges laid after 'trail of destruction' and rock thrown at firefighters in regional SA

image.altText: Three little penguins bunched together on sand

props.synopsis: The small, fragile colony of surviving little penguins on South Australia's Granite Island records a "significant increase" in numbers amid the state's harmful algal bloom.

title.children: 'Very fat' baby penguins raise hopes for SA colony despite algal bloom

image.altText: A man and woman walking down the street, covering their heads with jackets

props.synopsis: A Perth mother jailed for starving her only child to the point of severe malnutrition is denied bail after arguing she should be released because she had not been given a fair trial.

title.children: 'Selfish' mother who starved teen ballerina daughter has bail bid rejected

image.altText: Conjoined newborn twins lie amongst blankets in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: The mother of a rare set of conjoined twins is begging doctors to explore other options after a Papua New Guinea hospital recommended against sending the infants overseas for surgery.

title.children: Not the end of the road for PNG conjoined twins, hospital says

image.altText: A generic image of a red Australian rules ball.

props.synopsis: A suburban Perth football club is suspended from its league for two years after a "severe breach" of integrity standards, following an end-of-season costume stunt that left City of Stirling workers distressed.

title.children: Stephen Hawking costume sees Perth football club banned for two years

image.altText: A centrlink sign through a bush.

props.synopsis: Fugitives wanted for some of the most serious crimes and sexual offences could soon be stripped of their welfare payments.

title.children: Fears fugitive welfare cut-off will capture innocent people

image.altText: Hektoria Glacier eastern Antarctica

props.synopsis: Antarctic scientists have documented the fastest retreat of a glacier in modern history, after it lost eight kilometres of ice in just two months, according to a new report.

title.children: Antarctic glacier shrinks at fastest pace in modern history

image.altText: Reserve Bank of Australia

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has kept interest rates on hold at 3.6pc after hotter-than-expected inflation in the September quarter squashed hopes of a rate cut.

title.children: RBA keeps rates on hold in November at 3.6pc

image.altText: A street sign that reads "Wall St". A US flag is visible behind it.

props.synopsis: Last week the RBA governor issued a blunt warning on the state of financial markets and as markets continue to shift from traditional valuation methods, plenty of cool heads are getting nervous.

title.children: A key measure of stock market health is now flashing red

image.altText: A woman in a pale pink suit in parliament, in front of a row of benches.

props.synopsis: While conservatives are waiting for the net zero issue to be resolved, those who support Andrew Hastie or Angus Taylor for the leadership say her leadership will likely be threatened after the summer break.

title.children: Sussan Ley almost certain to face challenge next year, detractors say

image.altText: An aerial view of housing developments on the edge of farming areas.

props.synopsis: Communal living was once common in regional Australia. Now an investigation is underway into whether it could help ease the housing crisis.

title.children: Building more homes on farmland touted as solution to housing crisis

image.altText: Sunrise over a silhouetted jetty and calm water.

props.synopsis: For some residents of Tasmania's east coast, it's either leave the region or risk being homeless as they grapple with a scarcity in long-term rentals.

title.children: 'The very best place in Australia' is running out of homes

image.altText: A woman with long wavy brown hair, wearing a navy lace top, standing in a suburban street.

props.synopsis: I want to reflect on what I have come to see, through my own experience, as both the illuminating strengths and the shadowed weaknesses of the Australian legal system and its role in our democracy.

title.children: At the heart of the constitution, there lies an historic and structural wound

image.altText: A man smiling.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump has thrust the Democrats into the political wilderness but an uprising in the gritty streets of New York may be their future.

title.children: Why a 'radical' Democrat socialist is causing waves in the United States

image.altText: A close-up of a bag of blue pills, held by hands in blue gloves.

props.synopsis: Police charge 18 people in Perth and Sydney and seize 268 kilograms of illicit drugs following a multi-agency investigation into a national crime syndicate.

title.children: 'Put them out of business': Police seize $60 million of drugs in major bust

image.altText: Italian police officers in black clothes and berets standing guard in front of the Torre dei Conti, seen between two tree trunks

props.synopsis: A Romanian worker who was trapped for hours under rubble in Rome after the partial collapse of a 787-year-old medieval tower near the Colosseum has died, according to local media.

title.children: Worker dies after dramatic rescue from Italian medieval tower collapse

image.altText: NOLb_EskSolar_0211

props.synopsis: If solar panels at your property sustain hail damage, is there anything you can do to avoid further problems?

title.children: Giant hail left SEQ solar panels with gaping holes. Here's what you can do

image.altText: man with white wound dressings around his eye helps carry a coffin on a metal scaffold. marigold flowes on coffin.

props.synopsis: A passenger who walked from a Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner crash that killed his brother soon after take-off tells UK media of the mental and physical anguish he has endured since.

title.children: Lone survivor of Air India crash says 'God took all my happiness'

image.altText: A hill with a coal mine cut out of the side.

props.synopsis: BHP will transfer 3,700 hectares of land at the Mt Arthur coal mine to a neighbouring mining company looking to expand its operations, raising questions about its promise to close the mine by 2030.

title.children: BHP accused of backflipping on closure of NSW's biggest coal mine

image.altText: Police push back an angry crowd of protesters

props.synopsis: Dozens of demonstrators from Palestine Action Group rallied outside the Sydney International Convention Centre on Tuesday morning.

title.children: Thirteen arrested as pro-Palestinian protesters clash with police at defence expo

image.altText: A man wearing sunglasses with glitter up their cheekbones.

props.synopsis: For the LGBTQIA+ community, queer pubs and clubs can be an oasis. But in some capital cities they are vanishing.

title.children: By the end of the year, three capital cities could have no queer clubs

image.altText: toilet paper lines the toilet seat

props.synopsis: Public toilets are a "microbial soup" and there are things you should be doing to protect yourself — including not taking out your mobile phone and never hovering over the seat.

title.children: Beware the 'Trojan horse' of germs in public toilets

image.altText: Jofra Archer on the cricket field pointing with both hands, Ben Stokes rests his hands on JArcher's shoulders

props.synopsis: England is urged to play both Jofra Archer and Mark Wood to begin the Ashes in Perth despite durability concerns with both quicks.

title.children: Aussie great urges England to unleash pacemen despite injury concerns

image.altText: Men in military attire holding shields with a person and a dog appearing behind them

props.synopsis: Israel's top military lawyer is behind bars after leaking a video of shocking alleged abuse of a Palestinian man in a military jail. This is why the case has shaken politics and the military to the core.

title.children: A leaked video showed an alleged abuse. It has sparked a political fight in Israel

image.altText: A crowd of tourists taking photos outside Beijing Railway Station

props.synopsis: The extension, which is until the end of 2026, covers 32 European countries as well as Australia, New Zealand, Japan, South Korea and several nations in South America and the Gulf region.

title.children: China extends visa-free entry for 45 countries, including Australia

image.altText: A close-up photo of destruction to Afghanistan's Blue Mosque after an earthquake

props.synopsis: The centuries-old Blue Mosque site, one of Afghanistan's most revered religious landmarks, is a major gathering place during Islamic and cultural festivals.

title.children: Earthquake kills at least 20, damages Afghanistan's ancient Blue Mosque
